docs.lead_paragraph: HER first burial in a trash heap was an ignominious affair attended only by the mother who dumped her and the Yaphank recycling center employees who discovered her remains days later, on Feb. 7. The first town employee to see the body said he thought at first that the infant, wrapped in a plastic bag, was a discarded doll. Her second burial, on March 19, had all the ceremony and solemnity of a hero's funeral. An honor guard flanked the mourners' route into Mary Immaculate Church in Bellport; bagpipers played ''Amazing Grace'' as two police pallbearers carried her coffin, not much bigger than a breadbox; not one but two priests presided over the funeral Mass; cruisers from the Suffolk and Nassau police blocked off every intersection along the route as a cavalcade with an escort of Blue Knights, the motorcycle-riding off-duty police officers, accompanied the hearse from the church to Holy Rood Cemetery in Westbury.
docs.abstract: Article explores question of whether Suffolk County and New York State laws, meant to prevent deaths of abandoned newborn babies, are helping to save lives; laws permit parent to drop off newborn at hospital, police station, firehouse or with any 'appropriate person' within five days of birth--no questions asked, no criminal prosecution; number of dead infants found since laws were enacted in 2000 on Long Island was six while those safely relinquished numbered seven; funeral of Angela Hope, name given to newborn whose remains were found at Yaphank recycling center, described; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Since New York State enacted a law in 2000 meant to prevent the deaths of abandoned newborns, six infants have been found dead on Long Island, nearly equaling the number safely relinquished.

docs.lead_paragraph: HE was a ninth grader when the gambling addiction was born. ''It started with me with $5, New York Knicks versus Houston Rockets,'' said the 18-year-old graduate of Scarsdale High School, who asked to remain anonymous, ''and a couple of years later I was betting $7,000 on a game.''

headline.main: Fun, Obviously. But Is It Really Good and Clean?

docs.abstract: Article on gambling addictions among adolescents, which is becoming growing problem in Westchester County, NY; Frank Limone, coordinator of Problem Gambling Recovery Program at Westchester Jewish Community Services in Mamaroneck, says parents and teachers are not yet aware that teenagers are spending more time and money playing poker and gambling, including on the Internet; photos (L)

byline.original: By AVI SALZMAN and DAVID SCHARFENBERG

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. JAMES AIKINS was visiting his hometown of Cape Coast, in Ghana, in 2001 when he met the 21-year-old daughter of a cousin who was about to give birth. ''I told her not to go into labor because I don't catch babies anymore,'' recalled Dr. Aikins, who is a specialist in gynecological oncology with Cooper Health System in Camden. ''We all laughed.'' With that, the 47-year-old Dr. Aikins said, he went off to visit relatives in another part of the country. But when he returned to Cape Coast, he learned that although a healthy baby had been born, the mother bled to death two days later as a result of a postpartum hemorrhoid, a routine complication in the United States.
docs.abstract: Aricle on International Healthcare Volunteers, grass-roots organization made up of New Jersey doctors and nurses that has for past three years sponsored two-week-long medical missions to Ghana; Dr James Aikins, native Ghanian who is specialist in gynecological oncology in Camden and who founded organization, comments; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It is almost beyond belief, given the sea of distance between them now, that Terri Schiavo's husband and parents once shared a home, a life, a goal. But for years -- when Ms. Schiavo walked and talked among them and after her catastrophic collapse -- the headstrong young man and his traditionalist in-laws were, by all accounts, friendly.

headline.main: Behind Life-and-Death Fight, A Rift That Began Years Ago

docs.abstract: Once friendly Schiavo and Schindler families have been driven apart by disagreement over fate of brain-damaged Terri Schiavo; her husband, Michael, has argued for removal of her feeding tube, while her parents and siblings disagree; theirs is a battle over power, money and a woman they all claim to love; Michael Schiavo filed malpractice suit against obstetrician who had treated his wife, and in Jan 1993, couple was awarded $750,000 in economic damages for her and $300,000 for loss of companionship for him; both sides say a fight over award signaled beginning of their estrangement; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As Terri Schiavo lay dying in a hospice, a transfixed nation wondered how a 12-year-old fight ever became so bad.

docs.lead_paragraph: Directed by Eléonore Faucher 88 minutes 6 p.m. tomorrow, Alice Tully Hall; 9 p.m. Saturday, Museum of Modern Art Desperate to hide her pregnancy, 17-year-old Claire (Lola Neymark) has moved out of her parents' house and into tastefully dishabille quarters, where she embroiders bits of cloth with painstaking detail. The metaphorically minded should not be surprised that Ms. Faucher builds her trifle of a story much like Claire works her embroidery: piece by precious piece. Among the shinier bits are a young man (Thomas Laroppe) who brings heat to Claire's chilly existence and a grieving mother (Ariane Ascaride) who brings it some bite.

docs.lead_paragraph: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey yesterday signed into a law a bill requiring hospitals to provide rape victims with what are known as emergency contraceptives. The new law makes it mandatory for doctors to administer pregnancy tests to victims of sexual assault. If the tests show no pregnancy, the hospital would then be required, if the victim requests them, to provide the victims with prescriptions for the pills. They contain a higher dose of the hormone found in ordinary birth control pills and are most effective if taken within five days after sexual intercourse. Josh Benson (NYT)

headline.main: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Contraception Bill Signed

docs.abstract: Acting Gov Richard J Codey signs into law bill requiring doctors in hospitals to administer pregnancy tests to sexual assault victims and, if they are not pregnant, offer victims emergency contraceptives; photo (S)

byline.original: By Josh Benson (NYT); Compiled by Anthony Ramirez

docs.lead_paragraph: Rubella, a virus that once caused tens of thousands of birth defects and deaths in a single outbreak, has been eliminated from the United States, health officials say. But Americans must still vaccinate their children, and pregnant women must still ensure they are immune, because the disease exists elsewhere, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said. The agency said that in 2004, nine rubella cases were reported in the United States, all originating in other countries. Rubella, also known as German measles, is a usually mild viral infection that causes fever and rash, but early in pregnancy it can cause birth defects.

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: No More Rubella

docs.lead_paragraph: The reason for all the excitement, one public health doctor after another trooping into her mud-walled room to have a look, was that Patience Solomon had correctly hung her new royal blue mosquito net over the bed she shared with her 2-year-old son, James. Mosquito nets are not terribly complicated, as long as you have something to suspend them from -- in Mrs. Solomon's case, a hand-hewn rafter just at head-knocking height beneath her corrugated iron roof.
docs.abstract: Carter Center, health and peace organization, and Roll Back Malaria, World Health Organization campaign, combine efforts and provide medicine and mosquito nets to Somji, Nigeria; plan is scheduled to be implemented in all of Niger and Plateau, two central Nigerian States, but donations of mosquito nets have fallen short; both Lymphatic Filariasis and malaria could be drastically reduced by consistent use of mosquito nets; experts disagree on whether mosquito nets should be distributed free or sold at lower than average costs and marketed to those who need protection; Lymphatic Filariasis can be treated and cured, but pregnant women or children under five cannot be given medication and mosquito netting is best available line of defense for them against illness; difficulties faced by aid organizations and workers discussed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Mosquito nets are technically very simple but in their own mundane way, in rural Africa, they are highly political objects.
